message: I routinely want to clear out all open buffers.  I use FuzzyFinder's <Leader>b a lot to switch between things, so having 20 or 30 files open adds more noise.  As I understand it `%bd` should kill everything and some times it does.  Any ideas what might keep it from deleting all of the buffers?
Heh, I use vim in almost the exact opposite way.  I keep everything open.  Current buffer count is around 140.
It's not perfect, but it works most of the time.

I put that together using bits from the solutions posted here http://stackoverflow.com/questions/2974192/how-can-i-pare-down-vims-buffer-list-to-only-include-active-buffers and here http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1534835/how-do-i-close-all-buffers-that-arent-shown-in-a-window-in-vim
@dz wow that is a huge buffer count... may I ask, how do you open a buffer you need? just `:b` ?
FuzzyFinder's buffer listing lets you search buffers in real-time with fuzzy matching, it's not that big a deal if you have many buffers.
@nelstrom So what's the actual difference here.  `%bd` deletes visible buffers?  How is "visible" defined?
@dag I use FuzzyFinder as well and Command-T to search the file system for files that aren't open.  I like clearing out all my buffers when I'm switching tasks though.
@tswicegood actually, I think :%bd deletes all "listed" buffers. i.e. those that appear in when you run the command :ls

If :%bd fails to delete all of your buffers, it may be because you have made changes to a buffer and not saved it. In Vim's terminology, that is called a 'hidden' buffer (:help hidden-buffer) - which means it is not currently displayed in any windows or tabs, but it is still in the buffer list.
running :%bd! should delete all buffers, even the 'hidden' ones with unsaved changes.
@tswicegood I can't find anything in Vim's documentation about the meaning of the `%` sign when running :%bd - where did you come across it?

The gist that I posted above deletes everything in the buffer list that is not currently visible in any windows or tabs. It's not quite what you were asking for, but I find it useful when I want to pare down the buffer list without loosing the files that I already have open.

@nelstrom I'm not sure where I came across it.  Might have been me experimenting with it as a wildcard (i.e., :%s/foo/bar/ translates "%" to every thing instead of particular lines.  I can use 1,100bd to delete through buffers 100 (though I routinely have to do 1,200bd).  I'm not sure if I've tried `:%bd!` yet.  I vaguely recall doing so because of issues with unsaved buffers I didn't care about.
